newsitem.title: BELGIUM: BELGIAN BELGACOM MOBILE TO APPEAL COURT RULING.
newsitem.headline: BELGIAN BELGACOM MOBILE TO APPEAL COURT RULING.

text.p: Belgacom Mobile, which operates Belgium's Proximus mobile phone service, said on Friday it would appeal against a court ruling which said it must suspend a planned January sales promotion.

In a statement Belgacom Mobile said a Brussels court decided on Thursday provisionally to ban its Proximus promotion planned for this month following a complaint by rival GSM mobile phone network operator, Belgian-French company Mobistar.
"Belgacom Mobile/Proximus will appeal against this decision," the statement added.
Meanwhile there would be no publicity about its sales and it had asked its distributors to stop the sales programme.
Belgacom Mobile spokesman Luc De Groote said the court was applying the letter of the law which said companies could sell at a loss only directly to customers and not to distributors.
"(We) believe the legal provisions...do not benefit either the consumer or distributors," the statement said.
"The aim of Belgacom Mobile/Proximus is and will always be to make the market accessible to consumers by having yet more attractive prices."
"Belgacom Mobile/Proximus deplore having to stop their sales action. The consumer may feel duped," it added.
The statement said Belgacom Mobile clients currently totalled 409,000 - more than had been its target for 1996 - with 44,000 new clients having signed up in December.
Belgacom Mobile is a 75/25 venture between state telephone company Belgacom SA and AirTouch Communications Inc of the United States, which launched Proximus in January 1994.
Belgacom is 49.9 percent owned by a consortium including Ameritech ,Singapore Telecom and Tele Danmark and three Belgian groups. The rest is state owned.

Mobistar, which became operational in mid-1996, is owned 62 percent by France Telecom. Belgian data communications firm Telinfo NV has 10 percent and a group of eight other Belgian investors has the remaining 28 percent.
